events.name: GA Singapore: Hiring Event for UX Designers
events.description:
General Assembly welcomes companies to meet graduates of our User Experience Design Immersive Programs. Our UX Designers will be on hand to show off their projects, and are available to chat about job opportunities (GA does not charge any placement fees).

Come and let the newest UX talent in town show you that they mean business.

About Our Students

While our graduates all display a common set of skills and competencies, they each bring their own backgrounds and interests to their work as UX Designers. What you can expect are a group of proactive, creative and collaborative graduates.

Our User Experience Design Immersive Graduates

- Have undertaken lengthy, tested, structured training in User Experience Design from expert instructors
- Have fluency in UX methodology
- Have experience in User Research, business analysis, usability testing and content strategy
- Know how to sketch, prototype, and iterate on findings
- Are fluent in Sketch, InVision, Axure and multiple tools
- Have a solid design presentation technique
- Have knowledge on how to work in agile / lean environment
- Have a UX portfolio that shows complete process, not just an end result

What’s in it for you?
Priority access to the industry’s freshest talent.

Format

The event is structured as a reverse job fair. Graduates will be stationed at tables, showcasing their individual and team projects. Employers are free to engage each grad at their discretion. Graduates are looking for paid employment, apprenticeship roles, and many are open to either/both. Please discuss your preferences for hiring with graduates as you meet them. Try to view as many graduate portfolios as possible during the event - moving around the space will ensure you get the greatest exposure to the range of skill sour graduates have to offer.

Companies who have hired GA grads around the world

BBDO, Boston Globe Media, WSJ Custom Studios, Thoughtworks, PWC, Fairfax, Standard Chartered Bank, Sephora, and many more.

Please note: this is an exclusive event for companies who are looking to hire our General Assembly immersive graduates only.
events.location: General Assembly Singapore, 1 Keong Saik Road 089101

events.name: Making Sense of natural language with R
events.description: 18:30 - 19:00:  Networking 19:00 - 20:00:  Gaurav Chaturvedi, Lead Data Scientist at DBS "Making Sense of natural language with R" We'll look at the types of problems that can be solved using text mining tools in R. Case studies will be provided, along with key learning points & challenges that the presenter has encountered.  The presenter is Gaurav Chaturvedi, Lead Data Scientist at DBS. Gaurav has been using R for around 2 years.  Hope to see you there!
events.location: Microsoft Auditorium (Singapore), One Marina Boulevard, Level 21 Auditorium, Singapore 018989

events.name: Cloud Native Java - Josh Long
events.description: Josh (@starbuxman) is the Spring Developer Advocate at Pivotal. Josh is a Java Champion, author of 5 books (including O'Reilly's upcoming Cloud Native Java: Designing Resilient Systems with Spring Boot, Spring Cloud, and Cloud Foundry)  “It is not necessary to change. Survival is not mandatory.” -W. Edwards Deming Work takes time to flow through an organization and ultimately be deployed to production where it captures value. It’s critical to reduce time-to-production. Software - for many organizations and industries - is a competitive advantage. Organizations break their larger software ambitions into smaller, independently deployable, feature -centric batches of work - microservices. In order to reduce the round-trip between stations of work, organizations collapse or consolidate as much of them as possible and automate the rest; developers and operations beget “devops,” cloud-based services and platforms (like Cloud Foundry) automate operations work and break down the need for ITIL tickets and change management boards. But velocity, for velocity’s sake, is dangerous. Microservices invite architectural complexity that few are prepared to address. In this talk, we’ll look at how high performance organizations like Ticketmaster, Alibaba, and Netflix make short work of that complexity with Spring Boot and Spring Cloud.
events.location: PayPal office in Suntec, 5 Temasek Blvd, #09-01 Suntec Tower Five, 038985 Nearest Mrt:Promenade(Yellow Line), Singapore

events.name: IGDA x Facebook
events.description:
We're teaming up with Facebook to try a slightly different IGDA event this time, looking at how some developers successfully use Facebook to market their games and studios, and doing a series of 1:1 consultations with developers interested in optimizing the Facebook presence. 



WHAT TO EXPECT
Join us at Facebook Singapore to learn how your game can be discovered on Facebook. Hear from our resident gaming and advertising experts on how to set yourself up for success when marketing on Facebook and how to get the most bang for your buck on the platform. 

A limited number of developers will also be able to get 1:1 consultations with Facebook personnel. Registrations will be on a first-come basis and developers with existing Facebook pages and advertising accounts will be prioritized. 
AGENDA
6.30pm | Registration
7.00pm | Presentations – FB Marketing for Game Developers
8.00pm | Q&A
8.15pm | 1:1 Consultations & Networking
9.15pm | End of Event

If you want to sign up for the 1:1 Consultation, please use this RSVP form: https://goo.gl/l8oxHr

Otherwise, just sign up to the event as usual!

Hope to see you there, 
the IGDA Singapore team
events.location: Facebook Singapore, Level 22 South Beach Tower, 38 Beach Road,

events.name: Ruby Code Reading Group #3: Rack
events.description:
Hi everyone! The "How does it work?" meetup was inspired by Guo Xiang's suggestion to have a meetup talk about how Sprockets actually works. In our previous meetings we learned about Sprockets and Concurrent Ruby. This is our 3rd meetup and this time we'll dig into the code of Rack library. Rack (http://rack.github.io) is the most popular web server interface for Ruby libraries. It powers most of the Ruby web frameworks (Rails, Sinatra, Volt, Roda). Although used by many, Rack is understood by few people, and we'll change it a bit by learning how it works. Preparation Rack is quite a big library, therefore we'll focus on just 2 parts: server and handler. To prepare for the meetup: 1. Watch Aaron Patterson's presentation from RubyConf Taiwan 2015 (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u5AaZRVhecI - start from 24:00) 2. Read Rack handler's code: a) handler's selection (https://github.com/rack/rack/blob/master/lib/rack/handler.rb) b) example handler, let's use Webrick: (https://github.com/rack/rack/blob/master/lib/rack/handler/webrick.rb) 3. Read Rack server's code (https://github.com/rack/rack/blob/master/lib/rack/server.rb) 4. Play with the code - write a simple Rack application, run it, try to see what happens when you do it. 5. Prepare some small snippet of code that you can show to other people - it can be either very small app, or some call of Rack internals that you find interesting. 


See you soon!
